      • forwardWithTScaled

        public GenericPair<double[][],double[]> forwardWithTScaled(double[][][] a,
                                                  double[] pi,
                                                  java.lang.String[] y,
                                                  int N,
                                                  int T,
                                                  java.lang.String[] d,
                                                  java.util.HashMap<Pair,java.lang.Double> t_table)
        Computes forward algorithm for HMM. Note that we re-scale the probabilities to avoid 0 probabilities for long sentences. References: (1) wikipedia Baum Welch algorithm (2) Mathematics of HMM and
        Parameters:
        a - HMM transition parameters
        pi - HMM start parameters
        y - source sentence
        N - length of the target sentence
        T - length of the source sentence
        d - target sentence
        t_table - translation table
        Returns:
        a pair of alphaHat probabilities and c_hat (for alphaHat c_hat refer to reference (2))

        pi - HMM start parameters
        y - source sentence
        N - length of the target sentence
        T - length of the source sentence
        d - target sentence
        t_table - translation table
        c_scaled - c scaler (computed using forwardWithTScaled method)
        Returns:

      • tProbability

        public double tProbability(java.lang.String f,
                  java.lang.String e)

      • aProbability

        public double aProbability(int iPrime,
                  int i,
                  int I)
        Smoothes p(i|i',I) probabilities by backing-off to a uniform probability 1/I This is an alternative to Och and Ney, 2003 interpolation: \alpha*p(i|i',I) + (1-\alpha)*1/I.
        Parameters:
        iPrime - previous target position
        i - current target position
        I - length of target sentence
        Returns:
        either p(i|i',I) or back-off to 1/I

      • logViterbi

        public java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.Integer> logViterbi(int N,
                                                java.lang.String[] o,
                                                java.lang.String[] d)
        Computes Viterbi decoding algorithm for HMM-based word alignment for a given sentence pair. For handling source words that have no alignment in the target sentence, we add N empty words (NULLs) to the target sentence and follow Och and Ney (2000a) approach. This is implemented in multiplyOneMinusP0H method and is called before the logViterbi method is called for each sentence pair.
        Parameters:
        N - target sentence length
        o - source sentence
        d - target sentence
        Returns:
        the best target positions (which could be NULL) for source positions 1 to N.

      • multiplyOneMinusP0H

        public void multiplyOneMinusP0H(java.lang.String[][] bitext,
                       double p0H)
        Following Och and Ney (2000a) approach, for handling source words that have no alignment in the target sentence, we add N empty words (NULLs) to the target sentence and enforce a set of constraints which are implemented in this method.
        Parameters:
        bitext - source-target bitext
        p0H - probability of transition to NULL (refer to Och and Ney, (2000))

      • findBestAlignmentsForAll_AER

        public java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.String> findBestAlignmentsForAll_AER(java.lang.String[][] bitext,
                                                                 int num_lines,
                                                                 java.lang.String alignmentFile)
                                                                   throws java.io.IOException
        Finds the best alignments (source-target positions (1-1,2-3,3-5, ..., j-i, ..., N-x) for each sentence pair in the given bitext)
        Parameters:
        bitext - test bitext for which decoding should be done.
        num_lines - number of lines or sentences from the beginning of the bitext on which decoding should be done.
        alignmentFile - output alignment file.
        Returns:
        a list of alignments. Each alignment is a string of j-i (source-target) alignment positions.
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException
